field_edited_text.value:
Historical Background



of Planning had worked out several such interchange designs based upon
the East-West Expressway being depressed through the Mt. Vernon area.
The design generally regarded as the best was developed in the summer
of 1957 and is shown on Sheet 14. Federal officials viewed this design
unfavorably, however, holding that it was excessively costly and cumber-
some. A series of informal conferences was held with Federal officials in
the course of which many trial designs were developed and discarded.
Finally, a suggestion was made that a successful design might be possible
if the East-West Expressway approached the intersection from the west
as a double-decked elevated structure. The suggestion was fruitful in that
it did permit a complete intersection to be worked out which overcame
previous Federal objections, but it had the unfortunate corollary of
requiring the East-West Expressway to be elevated and double-decked
from Myrtle Avenue to the Jones Falls Expressway. The Planning Com-
mission was unhappy over this situation, but it appeared that no other
solution was feasible. Upon advice from the Department of Public Works
that a decision was necessary to avoid delay in the design of the Jones
Falls Expressway, the Planning Commission reluctantly approved the pro-
posed interchange design, informally in January of 1958, and formally
in May.

Four months later, on September 17, 1958, the Planning Commission
decided to reconsider this decision and instructed its staff to restudy the
interchange problem in the hope that a feasible scheme could be developed
that would allow the East-West Expressway to be depressed through the
Mt. Vernon area. The Commission’s reconsideration was a result of
several developments. In the first place, it became apparent that the need
for a decision on the interchange was not as urgent as it had previously
appeared. Next, further studies by the Department of Transit and Traffic
indicated that some of the interchange movements were less important



12

than had been assumed. And, finally, the original decision had precipi-
tated strong adverse public reaction.

Shortly after the Commission’s decision to reconsider, Mr. Robert O.
Bonnell, then chairman of the State Roads Commission, acting on a
suggestion from the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads, organized a committee
made up of various City, State and Federal officials. This committee,
generally referred to as the Bonnell Committee, was intended to serve as
a means for thrashing out differences of opinion on the expressway pro-
gram and for reaching agreements among all of the officials concerned.
While it was in existence the committee did resolve some unsettled points
in the design of the Jones Falls Expressway, but it was less successful on
reaching agreements on the East-West Expressway.

With respect to the interchange between the two expressways the
committee reviewed the latest traffic analysis figures prepared by Mr.
Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, and concluded
that four of the movements were of fundamental importance and must be
covered by the design. The four movements were from the north to the
east and reverse, and from the east to the south and reverse. It was also
agreed that two movements, from the west to the south and reverse, were
of such negligible importance that they could be forgotten. The remaining
two movements, from the north to the west and reverse, were of inter-
mediate importance and occasioned considerable discussion. Mr. Bonnell
suggested that the City explore the possibility of handling these move-
ments through surface streets, improving or widening them if necessary.
In accordance with this suggestion Mr. Barnes developed a proposal which
is shown on Sheet 20. Under this scheme, southbound traffic desiring to
go west on the East-West Expressway would leave the Jones Falls Ex-
pressway at the North Avenue interchange and proceed along Mt. Royal
Terrace and Cathedral Street to a connection with the East-West Ex-
